topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the episode series on SaaS-to-AI transformations and tees up Intercom’s pivot to Fin, including the stakes (plateauing growth) and rapid prototyping after GPT-3.5.

topics.title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
topics.summary: Eoghan shares current performance: strong ARR growth vs public SaaS benchmarks, Fin’s rapid growth trajectory, and category leadership in customer experience agents.

topics.title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
topics.summary: Eoghan explains the company’s bloat and strategic dilution during his illness/absence, the post-COVID surge masking issues, and the slide toward zero net-new ARR that triggered his return.

topics.title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
topics.summary: They discuss how GPT-3.5 clarified disruption risk, Intercom’s existing AI team advantage, and how a working Fin beta emerged within six weeks—helped by Intercom’s data and customer base.

topics.title: From anti-bot stance to AI-as-personal
topics.summary: Eoghan reconciles Intercom’s original mission (“make internet business personal”) with AI agents, arguing instant expert help can be more personal than delayed human support; they broaden to AI superiority in some tasks.

topics.title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
topics.summary: Eoghan addresses Intercom’s historically unpopular, complex pricing driven by unfocused strategy, and describes cutting complexity—giving up significant ARR to rebuild trust and customer obsession.

topics.title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
topics.summary: Eoghan describes the messy cocktail behind the pivot: impatience, anger at diluted execution, desperation, and a deliberate shift to an authoritarian founder-led approach rather than committee-driven decisions.

topics.title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
topics.summary: They unpack Fin’s 99-cent-per-resolution model, early negative margins, and the rationale for value-aligned outcome pricing that customers perceive as fair and that improves retention and trust.

topics.title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
topics.summary: Eoghan details the turnaround playbook: aggressive cost cuts, narrowing to customer service, committing major capital to AI, rewriting values, and instituting performance/value scoring to reshape behavior.

topics.title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
topics.summary: They discuss internal backlash (letters to the board), Eoghan’s belief in strong CEO decision-making, and the resulting ~40% employee turnover as Intercom re-matched talent to the new mission and pace.

topics.title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
topics.summary: Eoghan reflects on why returning was cathartic despite daily stress, and contrasts the romanticized pivot narrative with the grind of executive work and corporate responsibilities.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ad read for DX, a developer intelligence platform measuring AI tool usage and engineering productivity impact.

topics.title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
topics.summary: They explore agent impact beyond CX, envisioning hybrid human-agent organizations, flatter structures, and agents even in high-level coordination roles, with deflationary effects and intensified competition.

topics.title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
topics.summary: Eoghan argues automation targets repetitive/demeaning work (including many CX and parts of sales), while human trust and connection remain valuable; they discuss AI’s effect on creative roles like podcasting.

topics.title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
topics.summary: Eoghan’s core lesson: AI disruption is inevitable and aggressive; companies must commit, recruit real AI leaders and young talent, and match the intensity of AI-native startups—or empower someone who will.
